mentions.context: MTG allows for the topological description of a plant at multiple, nested, spatial scales on the same graph.

MTG has been previously used in plant architecture analyses (Costes et al. 2003), in radiation interception (Da Silva, Han, and Costes 2014), as well as to simulate physiological processes (Fournier et al. 2010;Ndour et al. 2017;Barillot et al. 2018) or model plant-pathosystems (Garin et al. 2014(Garin et al. , 2018;;Robert et al. 2018) (albeit by using a single scale at a time).
MTG:

MuSCA is a generic, functional structural plant model (FSPM) (Vos et al. 2010) representing the carbon allocation and organ growth of a plant at different, user-defined, spatial scales, while taking into account competition and distances between carbon sinks and supplies present on the plant (Fig. 1).
MuSCA on different tree structures of apple trees, represented at multiple topological scales).
MuSCA still neglects to represent some important physiological implication of the distribution of sinks along the plant topology.
MAppleT combines markovian models for the simulation of growth unit succession and branching with a biomechanical model for axis bending.
MAppleT includes (i) Markov models for simulating annual shoot
In RATP the tree structure is first discretized into voxels of user-defined size.
In MuSCA, some of the plant properties available at one scale are used to provide a description of the same properties at a coarser (up-scaling) or finer (down-scaling) scale.

In MuSCA, the amount of C-assimilates available from photosynthesis in individual leaves is estimated with a radiative model: RATP: (Sinoquet et al. 2001) integrated within the OpenAlea platform and running on MTG structures (see also Supplementary Information: Inputs of the MuSCA model).
In MuSCA, the considered friction parameter (h, eq. 1) is empirical and does not correspond to a clear biological process.
The MuSCA model simulates biomass accumulation over a single vegetative season.
The MuSCA model could be further refined by using the MTG properties to increase the computational efficiency without losing prediction accuracy.
The QualiTree model represents growth and quality of fruits on a peach tree structure, at the fruiting unit (FU) scale, during a single growth season (Lescourret et al. 2011, Pallas et al. 2016).
In a MTG, sources and sinks are represented by vertices in a tree graph.

Each MTG vertex (i) is characterized, among other properties, by three dimensional coordinates (basal and top), the possibility to have a parent (named i-1), and one or multiple sons (the vertex i is the son of its parent).
In a MTG, a vertex at a coarser scale (I, called complex) is composed of one or more vertices at the finer scale (called components of I), as in the case of a shoot composed of several internodes.
Inputs of the MuSCA model).
In this study, MuSCA was applied on MTGs issued from the MAppleT architectural model (Costes et al. 2008).

The Tree Graph (MTG) (Godin and Caraglio 1998), a formalism inspired by the observation of the multi-scale organization of plant structures (Barthélémy 1991;Barthélémy and Caraglio 2007;Balduzzi et al. 2017).
To our knowledge, MuSCA is the first C-allocation model that allows simulating Callocation at multiple topological scales within a plant representation.
Computation time in MuSCA closely approximates a third order polynomial function of the number of represented plant components (Supplementary Information -Fig.
Regarding the use of MuSCA in the larger context, its generality can ease its adaptation to different species.

Indeed, in order to run MuSCA, the plant description should simply allow for the identification of the organ types (via the presence of leaves and fruits), their geometrical sizes (length and radiuses) and their topological connections (succession, branching).

The model reuses existing OpenAlea components, such as the MTG dynamic data-structure (Godin and Caraglio 1998; https://github.com/openalea/mtg),

By making a dynamic use of MTG (Godin and Caraglio 1998) the presented model allows us modifying the type of "individual entities" considered in source-sink exchanges within a plant structure on the fly.
For the basal vertex of the MTG, the only without a parent, coordinates are stored in the complex of the same vertex.
The input plant structures of MuSCA are MTGs where individual plant components are characterized by qualitative or quantitative information.
Two of them are commonly used in MTG (metamer and growth unit) and three are newly defined (trunk, branches and shoots; 1 st order branch and inter-branches; fruiting unit) (Fig. 3).
Further simulations and analyses with MuSCA performed by dynamically tuning the friction parameter values could help testing such behaviors.
In this study, a previous calibration of RATP for the apple trees, Fuji cultivar (Massonnet et al. 2006), was used.

In addition, the modular implementation of MuSCA in the OpenAlea environment facilitates the integration with other, previously developed, models, as it was the case for the connection with the MAppleT (Costes et al. 2008)   M scale (solid lines) and coarser scales (dashed lines).
The model is integrated in the open-source OpenAlea environment (Pradal et al. 2008(Pradal et al. , 2015) ) and implemented in the Python language.
In this paper, we provide an overview of the MuSCA model, define its scope and inputs,
The MuSCA model could be further refined by using the MTG properties to increase the computational efficiency without losing prediction accuracy.
These were MTGs of three apple trees simulated by the MAppleT architectural model (Costes et al. 2008).
The distance (dist i,j ) among two vertices (i, j) in a MTG depends on the sequence of vertices that connect i and j (called topological path).

In addition, the modular implementation of MuSCA in the OpenAlea environment facilitates the integration with other, previously developed, models, as it was the case for the connection with the MAppleT (Costes et al. 2008)   M scale (solid lines) and coarser scales (dashed lines).
In this study, MuSCA was applied on MTGs issued from the MAppleT architectural model (Costes et al. 2008).
The model reuses existing OpenAlea components, such as the MTG dynamic data-structure (Godin and Caraglio 1998; https://github.com/openalea/mtg),
used to represent the multiscale topology of plant structures, the PlantGL library (Pradal et al. 2009) used to represent the 3D geometry, and the RATP radiative model (Sinoquet et al. 2001).
However, MTGs coming from other sources, such as the several models present in the OpenAlea environment, could also be used, given their compliance with certain prerequisites.
All simulations were run on a computer equipped with an Intel i7-6700HQ 2.59 Ghz CPU, 8Gb RAM; OS: Windows 10 Home, 64bit.
It is important to remember that like other carbon allocation models applicable to large plant structures, MuSCA makes use of an empirical parameter (the friction parameter).
For instance, the individual fruit growth simulated at the FU scale can be compared with results obtained by QualiTree (Lescourret et al. 2011).

Supplementary Information: Input tree structures In the current application, input tree structures were MTGs produced by the MAppleT model (Costes et al. 2008).
